lesson.name: Unit 4: Part 1: Focus on the Teacher/Administrator

page.title: Introduction
page.contents:
This professional development module is part of a suite of related resources.  The suite includes the following resources:

  • Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction: Issue Brief
    This issue brief presents a broad overview of digital literacy as it relates to adult learners in English language acquisition programs. It is intended to serve as an introduction to the topic of digital literacy that teachers and administrators can use as a springboard to additional in-depth resources.

  • Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction: Companion Learning Resource

This digital magazine is a practical, comprehensive instructional resource written specifically for teachers. It provides numerous examples of instructional models, strategies, tools, and tasks for integrating digital literacy into English language instruction..  

The issue brief and companion learning resource can be found at

https://lincs.ed.gov/programs/eslpro

page.title: Definition of Digital Literacy
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-4.mp3

Audio transcript


Digital literacy includes a wide range of skills associated with using technology to enable users to find, evaluate, organize, create, and communicate information, including using basic digital skills in meaningful ways. It also means having the skills, strategies, and dispositions to use those skills to solve problems in increasingly technology-rich environments. These skills are important for participation in 21st century life, including education, work, and community.

  • The term digital literacy means the skills associated with using technology to enable users to find, evaluate, organize, create, and communicate information (U.S. Department of Education, 2015).

  • Digital literacy also means the ability to use those skills to solve problems in the increasingly technology-rich environments of 21st century life (Leu, Kinzer, Coiro, Castek, & Henry, 2013).

page.title: Welcome
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-5.mp3

Audio transcript


Welcome to Unit 4! This unit is part of an online module on integrating digital literacy into adult English language instruction. The four units in this professional development module parallel the definition of digital literacy, introduced on the previous page.

Unit 1 focuses on basic digital literacy skills, the importance of digital literacy, and ways to integrate digital literacy meaningfully into instruction. It is a good idea to start with Unit 1 and then move to any of the other units. Unit 2 focuses on information and communication technologies and the ways that creating and communicating information digitally also promote English language learning. Unit 3 looks at digital information literacy and ways to help students learn to find, understand, and critically evaluate information on the Internet. Unit 4 (this unit) incorporates a wide range of digital literacies into problem solving in technology-rich environments and is for teachers who have already been integrating digital literacy into their practice and want to take this integration further. By participating in this unit, teachers, professional developers, and administrators can learn ways to use information and communication technologies to enhance opportunities for their adult English-language-learning students to increase their English language acquisition and their digital literacy skills at the same time.

Welcome to Unit 4 of the module on Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction!

Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our lives

Unit 2: Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning

Unit 3: Digital Information Literacy

Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich Environments

While this unit can be done on its own, it is best if you first do Unit 1, “Digital Literacy in Our Lives.”

page.title: Organization of This Unit
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-5B.mp3

Audio transcript


The first part of this unit will focus on you, the teacher (or administrator) and will help you to think about the ways that problem solving in technology-rich environments is part of your life, without your having necessarily defined it that way. Throughout this unit, problem solving in technology-rich environments will often be abbreviated as PSTRE. In Part 2, the focus shifts from you to the student, and the ways that problem solving in technology-rich environments is embedded in their lives as adults living in the United States and as English language learners in a new culture. Defining the concept of problem solving and its five components is the focus of this section. In Part 3, the focus shifts to instruction, and the way to design activities that integrate PSTRE into lessons and units.

Part 1: Focus on the Teacher

  • Defining Problem Solving in Technology-Rich Environments (PSTRE)

  • Reflective Activity

Part 2: Focus on the Student

  • Five Steps in Problem Solving

Part 3: Problem Solving in English Language Acquisition

  • How To Design a PSTRE Activity

  • Final Activity

page.title: Certificate of Completion
page.contents:
You can earn a certificate of completion by completing the three unit activities.

To earn a certificate of completion, you will need to do the following:

  • Complete a reflection activity.

  • Design a PSTRE activity and describe it.

page.title: Defining Problem Solving in Technology-Rich Environments
page.contents:
Context


As you know, technology permeates daily life in the areas of work and education. Increasingly it permeates community and family life, as well. These technology-rich environments are complex and involve problem-solving situations. For example, most information is now available online, but websites are complex; there are many different types, and they can be difficult to understand. Also, online information is nonlinear. You usually need to follow a series of links to find the information that you are seeking, but it may not be clear how that information is related to the previous information or the bigger picture. In addition, tasks done in technology-rich environments are not usually routine. Each task usually requires figuring out something new, which could be where the important information is; which app is needed and how to download it; whether the site is secure enough for personal information, and so forth. Nonroutine tasks are far more difficult than routine tasks that do not require much thought.

Technology permeates daily life in the areas of work, education, community, and even family.

Technology-rich environments present complex problem-solving situations for people.

  • Websites are complex, and there are many different types.

  • Nonlinear linking of information can be overwhelming.

  • Most tasks are not handled through simple routines.

page.title: Defining Problem Solving in Technology-Rich Environments for Adult ELLs
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-9.mp3

Audio transcript


Technology-rich environments are especially difficult for adult English language learners to navigate. Technology-rich environments are linguistically complex, as well as technologically complex. For example, English language learners are working in a new language, which makes a complex environment even more difficult. Many English language learners need to manipulate oral, written, and multimedia resources in multiple languages to work through digital environments. English language learners may need to use language support tools, such as page readers, lookup tools in applications, or translation tools. This is part of the way that English language learners use technology to solve problems. In addition, websites are often based on cultural knowledge and make assumptions that are unfamiliar. For example, a job search website categorizes the job search and even jobs into categories that are based on cultural assumptions about the job search process and how jobs are perceived. Making the process even more difficult, reading online requires reading skills and critical approaches that are counter to the cultural and educational experiences of many. PSTRE requires a whole host of digital skills.

Technology-rich environments are especially difficult for adult English language learners. Technology-rich environments are linguistically complex, as well as technologically complex.  

For example:

  • ELLs are working in a new language, which makes a complex environment even more difficult.

  • Websites are often based on cultural knowledge and make assumptions that are unfamiliar.

  • Reading online requires reading skills and critical approaches that are counter to the cultural and educational experiences of many.

page.title: Defining PSTRE
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-10.mp3

Audio transcript


Throughout this module, in the various units, several different aspects of digital literacy have been the focus, including Unit 1, digital literacy in our lives, which focuses on foundational digital skills; Unit 2 which focuses on ways to create and communicate information for language learning; and Unit 3, which focuses on finding and evaluating information. As illustrated in the graphic, PSTRE includes all those elements and adds problem solving. Problem solving and digital literacy come together in PSTRE.

Throughout this module, several different aspects of digital literacy have been the focus of individual units:

  • Digital literacy in our lives—foundational digital skills.

  • Create and communicate information for language learning.

  • Find and evaluate information—Internet searching.

PSTRE includes all these aspects of digital literacy, as well as the aspect of problem solving.

page.title: Three Dimensions of Problem Solving
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-12.mp3

Audio transcript


For adult English language learners, problems are not only embedded in technology but are also embedded in a new language and culture. For adult English language learners, there are three dimensions of problem solving—the technological dimension, the cognitive dimension and the multilingual dimension. The multilingual dimension includes the oral, written, and multimedia resources used in multiple languages, including such language support tools as screen readers, application-specific lookup tools, and page translators. One of the ways that English language learners can use technology to solve problems is to employ these types of language support tools.

For ELLs solving a problem in a technology-rich environment has three dimensions: the technological, the cognitive, and the multilingual dimensions.

Adapted from the Program for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC) Expert Working Group in Problem Solving in Technology-Rich Environments (2009), p. 11, and S. Reder, personal communication (2015, May 19).

page.title: Problem Solving
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-11.mp3

Audio transcript


People encounter problems in day-to-day life in the multiple roles that they play, including roles as workers, citizens, consumers, and family members. Many, if not most, of these problems are embedded in technology of some kind. In general, problem solving in technology-rich environments, or PSTRE, has two dimensions: the technological and the cognitive. The technological dimension includes the devices, applications, and functionalities in which the problem is embedded and through which the problem may be solved. One example is using the Internet to find the address of a pharmacy after a late-night visit to the emergency room, when the prescriptions are electronically delivered to an unfamiliar pharmacy. The cognitive dimension includes the mental structures and the process by which a person solves the problem.

Solving a problem in a technology-rich environment has two dimensions: the technological dimension and the cognitive dimension.

Adapted from the Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC) Expert Working Group in Problem Solving in Technology-Rich Environments (2009), p. 11.

page.title: Defining PSTRE: An Example
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-13.mp3

Audio transcript


A good way to think about the steps to PSTRE is to work through an example. The Online Job Search Problem is a good example because many of the English language learners in your classes and programs have getting a job or a better job as one of their goals. It is also a focus of 2014 national legislation, the Workforce Innovation and Opportunities Act, which brings a new focus to college and career readiness in adult English language acquisition programs. In this problem, the student wants a new or different job and is looking through online job search websites that have been identified. The student does not want to have to register or pay a fee. The task is to bookmark the sites of interest. The solution involves looking at each identified site to determine whether registration or a fee is required. The student has to monitor where he or she is on the site and navigate around it to find the needed information. In the next pages this example, as well as several others, will be used to illustrate the steps in problem solving.

Online Job Search Problem:

The Problem: You want a (different) job and are looking through online job search websites. A friend already did a search and identified five websites for you. You don’t want to have to register or pay a fee. Bookmark all the sites that you are interested in.

The Solution: At each site you need to determine if there is registration or a fee required. One site clearly requires a registration. Click back to the search results. The next website doesn’t provide information about registration and fees on the first page. You have to look at options to select a link to where you may find that information. Several of the websites are complex and take quite a bit of clicking to find out whether registration or a fee is required. In each case, you have to get all the way back to the search result to go to the next website. Bookmark the job search websites that you select.

Adapted from the presentation by Anne Britt, Problem Solving in Technology-Rich Environments.

page.title: Defining PSTRE: An example
page.contents:
The difficulty of this problem is influenced by a variety of factors. This problem is somewhat difficult for the following reasons. Click each to learn more.

Goal Setting

 

Read more


This problem does not require goal setting because the goal was already set (the goal was to bookmark websites that did not require a fee or registration).

Monitoring

 

Read more


The solution to this problem requires self-organizing (you need to monitor whether each site meets the criteria). You can’t get distracted by other sites that you encounter.

Accessing Information

 

Read more


Accessing the information requires selecting multiple links and reading a variety of pages to find the information.

Evaluating the Information

 

Read more


Evaluating the information requires judging each job search website by the criteria (the criteria are that the job search site not require registration or a fee).

Making Use of the Information

 

Read more


Making use of the information requires using a bookmarking tool to bookmark the sites that meet the criteria.

Technology in the Task

 

Read more


Accomplishing the technological task requires two different types of tools (an Internet browser and an embedded bookmarking tool).

page.title: Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies: Results for the United States
page.contents:
U.S. Department of Education. Institute of Education Sciences, National Center for Education Statistics. (2013, November 12).
The Program for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC)—Executive Summary.
Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UgRwgFD-Ynk and http://piaacgateway.com/videos/

The Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC) is an international survey of adult skills. The assessment measures

  • Literacy

  • Numeracy

  • PSTRE

In 2012, the PIAAC survey of adults was conducted in more than 20 countries. The main findings can be found here.

The video contains a brief summary of the results for the United States.

page.title: Selected PIAAC Findings in the United States
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-23.mp3

Audio transcript


The Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC) in 2013 included a Survey of Adult Skills that measured, among other things, skills in literacy, numeracy, and problem solving in technology-rich environments, and rated performance in five numbered levels for literacy and numeracy, and in three levels for problem solving. Thirty-six million adults in the United States were found to have low skills, scoring below Level 2 on the literacy assessment. In literacy, numeracy, and problem solving in a technology-rich environment, the United States has a high percentage of low performers: One in six adults has low literacy skills; one third are young; one third are immigrants. Two thirds of low-skilled adults (ages 16–65) are employed, and 40% have earnings in the bottom fifth of the wage spectrum. There are significant consequences for having low skills: Skills strongly affect economic growth, health, and civic participation.

Who has low skills and what are the consequences?

  • One is six adults has low literacy skills.

  • One third of low-skilled U.S. adults are young.

  • One third are immigrants.

  • Two thirds are employed.

  • Forty percent of low-skilled Americans have earnings in the bottom fifth of the wage spectrum.

  • What adults know and can do—not just how many years of education they complete—strongly affects economic growth.

  • Americans with low skills face much higher odds of poor health than their counterparts in other industrialized countries.

  • Low skills damage a sense of community and shared democracy by limiting civic participation.

Adapted from U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical, and Adult Education. (2015, February).

To Go Deeper


To learn more about the PIAAC results in the United States, go to the webpage America’s Adult Basic Skills Gap, at http://www.digitalpromise.org/blog/entry/americas-adult-skills-gap

page.title: PSTRE in the United States
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-24.mp3

Audio transcript


The PIAAC measure of PSTRE is not simply a measure of the ability to use technology or have digital skills. PSTRE measures the ability to solve complex problems that are embedded in technology. The PIAAC used computers— not tablets or smart phones—for their PSTRE measurement. One in seven adults did not take the PSTRE assessment, because they had never used a computer, they did not want to use a computer even if they had used one before, or they did not have the basic computer skills needed for doing the PSTRE. Adults in the United States ranked far below the international average and was 18th of 20 countries for PSTRE. A higher proportion of U.S. adults are at the lowest levels of digital problem solving when compared with the international average. In addition, young Americans, aged 16 to 24 years, performed lower in digital problem solving than the international average of their peers, a finding that surprises many.

  • Adults in the United States ranked 18th of 20 participating countries for PSTRE.

  • A higher proportion of U.S. adults are at the lowest levels of digital problem solving when compared with the international average.

  • Young adults (ages 16–24) performed lower than the international average of their peers.

American Institutes for Research. Problem Solving in Digital Environments infographic. Retrieved from http://piaacgateway.com/s/AIR_PIAAC_Infographic_2.pdf (used with permission).

To Go Deeper


To learn more about the PIAAC results on PSTRE and how it was assessed, see video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ulqirbv9Q5g#t=372 (17:54 minutes)

page.title: PSTRE in the United States: Immigrants
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-25.mp3

Audio transcript


Immigrants have lower levels of literacy, numeracy, and PSTRE than their U.S.-born counterparts. Thirty-seven percent of immigrant adults were below the lowest level of PSTRE, as compared with 18% of U.S.-born adults, and 17% of immigrant adults have no computer experience, compared with 3% of U.S.-born adults. It is important for teachers and administrators who work with adult English language learners to know that, while many of them do have some digital literacy, there is a significant proportion who do not. With limited English language and technology skills, it is unlikely that these adult English language learners will be able to acquire digital literacy skills without help.

  • Immigrants have low levels of proficiency
    on most scales, when compared with their
    U.S.-born counterparts.

    • Lower levels of literacy, numeracy and  problem solving in technology-rich environments

  • 37% of immigrant adults were below the lowest level of PSTRE, as compared with 18% of
    U.S.-born adults.

  • 17% of immigrant adults have no computer experience, compared with 3% of U.S.-born adults.

To Go Deeper


To learn more about the PIAAC results on PSTRE and how it was assessed, see video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ulqirbv9Q5g#t=372 (17:54 minutes)

page.title: Part 1: Focus on the Teacher/Administrator
page.contents:
To start learning about PSTRE, think about your own experiences. How are your skills for problem solving in technology-rich environments?

There are two options for this reflective activity:

1. Take the Education and Skills Online Assessment, the assessment used in the PIAAC survey; then report your score in the Reflective Activity page.

Or

2. Describe a situation in which you had a problem in a technology-rich environment. Were you able to solve it? What skills did you use to solve (or not solve) the problem?

To Keep in Mind

Now that you have thought about your own experience in PSTRE, keep in mind the skills that you have. As you learn about the components of problem solving, think about those skills and what skills your students will need as they encounter problems in technology-rich environments.

Identifying the skills that your students need will help you to develop a PSTRE activity for your classes.

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
